Article Title: OpenAI's ChatGPT is seeing user growth slow down in the US: What this means, competition and ...
Article Text:

ChatGPT sees fall in app downloads and time spent on the mobile app





ChatGPT’s mobile app may be losing steam, with new data from app intelligence firm Apptopia showing a slowdown in global download growth. According to the analysis, the app’s new user growth, measured by month-over-month percentage changes in global downloads, has been decelerating since April and is projected to decline by 8.1% in October.While ChatGPT continues to attract millions of daily downloads worldwide, the stalling growth rate signals a potential peak in its expansion. Apptopia’s data also reveals a leveling off in global daily active users (DAUs) over the past month, suggesting the app’s user base is stabilizing.Apptopia in its report attributes the slowdown to rising competition and changes to ChatGPT’s AI model, which may be impacting its appeal. Apptopia notes that ChatGPT’s average time spent per DAU and average sessions per DAU metrics were trending downward before the sharp rise of its competitor, Google’s Gemini, which shot up to the top charts in September thanks to the release of Google’s new AI image model, Nano Banana. However, the company noted that while Gemini’s growth may have impacted some of the more recent drops in ChatGPT’s core metrics, it doesn’t explain the overall trend completely.In the U.S., user engagement is declining. The average time spent per DAU has dropped 22.5% since July, and the number of sessions per DAU has fallen by 20.7%. This indicates that American users are spending less time in the app and opening it less frequently.However, user churn has stabilized, with fewer users experimenting briefly and then abandoning the app, pointing to stronger retention of its core audience.As the AI landscape evolves, ChatGPT’s mobile app faces new challenges in maintaining its growth trajectory.
Article Summary: ChatGPT’s mobile app may be losing steam, with new data from app intelligence firm Apptopia showing a slowdown in global download growth. Apptopia in its report attributes the slowdown to rising competition and changes to ChatGPT's AI model, which may be impacting its appeal.

Article Title: Facebook rolls out new Meta AI photo suggestion feature that allows its AI suggest edits to photos on your phone -- even when you haven’t shared
Article Text:
FILE (AP Photo/Jeff Chiu, File)

Meta to use photos in your phone train its AI models, when ...





Meta has launched a new AI-powered feature for Facebook , allowing its AI to suggest creative edits for unposted photos in users’ camera rolls. The feature, now available to all users in the US and Canada, was announced on Friday and offers opt-in sharing suggestions for posting AI-edited photos to Facebook Feeds and Stories. "We’re introducing a new Facebook feature that surfaces photos and videos and suggests fun edits and collages, making it easier to share your favorite moments," said the company in a post.Initially tested in June, the feature prompts users with a permission dialog to allow cloud processing of camera roll images. This enables Meta AI to generate creative ideas like collages, recaps, AI restyling, and birthday-themed edits. Users can disable the feature at any time.Meta emphasizes that unposted photos are not used to train its AI or for ad targeting unless users actively edit or share the media. However, agreeing to Meta’s AI Terms of Service permits the AI to analyze media and facial features to summarize content, modify images, or generate new content. "All suggestions are private to you and you decide what to share, when to share, and with whom.We don’t use media from your camera roll to improve AI at Meta, unless you choose to edit this media with our AI tools, or share," said Meta in its post.The company also uses photo metadata, such as dates and the presence of people or objects, to tailor suggestions, raising concerns about the depth of personal data accessed.This rollout follows earlier reports in June about a test phase, where Meta clarified it wasn’t using private photos for AI training but left open the possibility for future use under specific conditions. Now, with the feature live, users must weigh the creative benefits against potential privacy implications.
Article Summary: The feature, now available to all users in the US and Canada, offers opt-in sharing suggestions for posting AI-edited photos to Facebook Feeds and Stories. Meta emphasizes that unposted photos are not used to train its AI or for ad targeting unless users actively edit or share the media.

Article Title: They were trying to steal data for extortion: Microsoft on stopping hackers from targeting Teams users
Article Text:
Representative Image

“Vanilla Tempest, tracked by other security vendors as VICE SPIDER and Vice Society, is a financially motivated actor that focuses on deploying ransomware and exfiltrating data for extortion. The threat actor has used various ransomware payloads, including BlackCat, Quantum Locker, and Zeppelin, but more recently has been primarily deploying Rhysida ransomware

,”

How these hackers targeted Microsoft Teams users



Satya Nadella Steps Back to Focus on AI: Microsoft’s Major Reorganisation Explained





Microsoft has successfully stopped a wave of cyberattacks targeting people using its video conferencing tool Teams. The software giant was able to restrict these attacks by removing more than 200 digital keys that the hackers used to make their malicious software appear trustworthy. The company revealed that the hacking group, also known as Vanilla Tempest, was trying to deploy a type of harmful software called Rhysida ransomware . This software locks up a victim's files, and the hackers then demand money to unlock them, a practice known as extortion . The group carried out these attacks using fake advertisements on search engines and tricky website links. They created websites with addresses that looked a lot like the official Microsoft Teams site.Microsoft wrote in a blog post.When a Teams user visited one of these fake sites, they were prompted to download a file named "MSTeamsSetup.exe," the same name as the real Teams program.Once someone ran this file, it secretly put a hidden tool, called the Oyster backdoor, onto the computer.This hidden Oyster tool gave the hackers secret remote control over the infected systems. This allowed them to steal private files, run commands, and load the final Rhysida ransomware to lock up the data.Microsoft said that Vanilla Tempest is a group mainly focused on making money. They specifically aim to get into company computer networks to lock files with ransomware and steal data for extortion. While they've used other locking software before, they have been focusing mostly on Rhysida recently.
Article Summary: Microsoft has stopped a wave of cyberattacks targeting people using its video conferencing tool Teams. The company revealed that the hacking group, also known as Vanilla Tempest, was trying to deploy a type of harmful software called Rhysida. This software locks up a victim's files, and the hackers then demand money to unlock them.

Article Title: Amazon founder Jeff Bezos: I always advise to young people, 'Go work at ...'
Article Text:
From fry station to fortune



Real-world lessons over instant gratification







Amazon founder Jeff Bezos has an important and surprising piece of advice for young people who are dreaming of entrepreneurial success. Bezos said ‘Go work at McDonald’s.’ As reported by Fortune, in a recent interview, Bezos stressed on the importance of early work experience especially in the fast-paced, customer-facing environment. “I always advise young people: Go work at McDonald’s,” Bezos said. “You learn responsibility. You learn how to show up. You learn how to deal with people. You learn how to hustle.”For those unaware, Bezos started Amazon out of his garage in 1994. He believes that entry-level jobs such as those at McDonald’s tech foundational skills which are important for long term success. He emphasised that such small roles are necessary as they instill skill like discipline, resilience and the ability to handle pressure. These are the traits that many Gen Z entrepreneurs may overlook in their rush to build startups.The comments by Bezos come at a time when debate is growing over the value of traditional work experience versus the allure of instant digital success. With platforms like TikTok and YouTube offering rapid fame and monetization, Bezos’ advice serves as a reminder that grit and consistency still matter.Jeff Bezos also stressed that the working environments like McDonald’s exposes Gratification. He noted that the working environment such as McDonald’s expose young people to real world challenges such as managing time, dealing with customers and working as part of a team. Bezos argue that these experiences are more valuable than any theoretical knowledge or online hustle. “You don’t need to start a company at 20,” he added. “You need to learn how the world works first.”
Article Summary: Amazon founder Jeff Bezos has an important and surprising piece of advice for young people who are dreaming of entrepreneurial success. Bezos said ‘Go work at McDonald’s.’ He believes that entry-level jobs such as those at McDonald's tech foundational skills which are important for long term success.

Zoho's Arattai messaging app sees 100x traffic surge in three days







Union Home Minister Amit Shah on Wednesday announced his switch to Zoho Mail, India's homegrown email platform, seemingly ditching Google and Microsoft in a major push for indigenous technology. Sharing his new email address—amitshah.bjp@zohomail.in—on social media, Shah wrote: "Hello everyone, I have switched to Zoho Mail. Kindly note the change in my email address. For future correspondence via mail, kindly use this address."Shah's move follows a broader government push toward self-reliance in digital infrastructure. IT Minister Ashwini Vaishnaw last month announced his transition to Zoho's office suite for documents, spreadsheets, and presentations. The Ministry of Education has also directed officials to adopt Zoho's productivity tools, marking a strategic shift away from foreign software dependency.This comes against the backdrop of US tariff pressures, with Prime Minister Narendra Modi's 'Swadeshi' campaign encouraging Made-in-India products to foster economic growth and innovation.Zoho co-founder Sridhar Vembu expressed gratitude for the endorsement, dedicating the moment to engineers "who have toiled hard in Zoho for over 20 years."The government's backing extends beyond email. Zoho's messaging app Arattai, launched in 2021, recently witnessed explosive growth with daily sign-ups jumping from 3,000 to 350,000 in just three days—a 100-fold increase. Education Minister Dharmendra Pradhan praised Arattai as "secure, user-friendly, and completely free," helping it climb India's app store charts.The Tamil-named app—meaning "casual chat"—offers one-on-one and group messaging, multimedia sharing, and audio-video calls with end-to-end encryption. It works across devices including desktops and Android TVs, featuring stories, broadcast channels, and business tools.Zoho founder Sridhar Vembu admitted the surge came before a planned November update, recalling how the project once seemed "hopelessly foolish" even to company employees.
Article Summary: Union Home Minister Amit Shah announced his switch to Zoho Mail, India's homegrown email platform. Article Title: Google to invest €5 billion in AI and data centres in Belgium, creating hundreds of jobs
Article Text:
Image: Shutterstock



Google expands AI infrastructure and data centres

Strengthening Belgium’s digital future

AI’s potential for economic growth





US tech giant Google has announced plans to invest €5 billion ($5.8 billion) in Belgium to expand its AI infrastructure and data centre network, creating hundreds of new jobs and supporting local economic growth. The investment will focus on the company’s existing Saint-Ghislain site and the new Farciennes campus, with construction already underway. Google said the expansion will strengthen Belgium’s role in Europe’s cloud and AI sector, provide large-scale computing capacity powered by carbon-free energy, and create opportunities for local suppliers and contractors. Officials highlighted the move as a vote of confidence in Belgium’s tech ecosystem and workforce.The investment will modernise and expand Google’s network of data centres in Saint-Ghislain and Farciennes, enabling the company to handle large volumes of digital data and support advanced AI systems. These facilities are designed to operate entirely on clean energy, aligning with Google’s global goal to achieve carbon-free operations by 2030. The expansion will also support the development of new onshore wind farms in Belgium to power the centres sustainably.The project is expected to create around 300 new full-time jobs directly, while indirectly supporting approximately 15,000 additional roles through local contractors and partners. Google already works with about 150 Belgian suppliers, including 80 in Wallonia, and the expansion will further boost construction, technology, and service sector employment. Prime Minister Bart De Wever emphasized that the investment underscores Belgium’s growing importance as a digital and green technology hub.Belgium has become a key location for technology growth thanks to its reliable internet networks, stable power supply, and skilled workforce. Google Cloud already serves Belgian companies and organizations such as Odoo and UZ Leuven, helping them scale AI-based tools for healthcare, research, and business. The new investment will enhance Belgium’s competitiveness in the European cloud and AI market, attracting further international investment and innovation.A 2024 study commissioned by Google estimated that artificial intelligence could increase Belgium’s GDP by €45 to €50 billion over the next decade. Most jobs are expected to be supported or improved by AI, with only a small portion at risk of automation. By expanding AI infrastructure, Google aims to equip Belgian companies and the workforce with advanced digital tools while fostering sustainable and inclusive growth. The investment positions Belgium as a hub for next-generation AI innovation in Europe. It also signals Google’s commitment to combining technological advancement with environmental responsibility, shaping the future of digital and green growth.
Article Summary: Google plans to invest €5 billion ($5.8 billion) in Belgium to expand its AI infrastructure and data centre network. The investment will focus on the company’s existing Saint-Ghislain site and the new Farciennes campus. The project is expected to create around 300 new full-time jobs directly, while indirectly supporting approximately 15,000 additional roles.

Sharing his new email address—amitshah.bjp@zohomail.in—on social media, the Home Minister requested all future correspondence be directed to his Zoho account, marking a symbolic shift away from global platforms like Gmail and Outlook.The move aligns with the government's broader push for digital sovereignty. IT Minister Ashwini Vaishnaw recently transitioned to Zoho's office suite, while the Ministry of Education has directed officials to adopt the company's productivity tools under the "Strengthening Digital Sovereignty under Swadeshi Movement" initiative.Zoho Mail, launched in 2008, offers secure, ad-free email hosting with encrypted transmission and two-factor authentication.Its servers are primarily hosted in India and the United States, appealing to organisations prioritising data protection and privacy.The government backing has yielded dramatic results beyond email. Zoho's messaging app Arattai witnessed explosive growth, with daily sign-ups surging from 3,000 to 350,000 in three days—a 100-fold increase following ministerial endorsements.For Vembu, Shah's adoption represents vindication of Zoho's two-decade commitment to building world-class technology from India. Founded in 1996, the company has maintained its "built in India, for the world" philosophy without seeking external venture capital, instead focusing on long-term talent development from rural India.The exchange between government and industry has resonated strongly with India's "Make in India" community, signaling the country's growing confidence in homegrown digital infrastructure.
Article Summary: Government push fuels Zoho's growing adoption across India. Zoho co-founder Sridhar Vembu expressed heartfelt gratitude to Union Home Minister Amit Shah after the latter announced his switch to Zoho Mail. Shah's announcement came as a significant endorsement for the Chennai-based tech company.

Article Title: ScaleAl, in which Mark Zuckerberg invested $14.3 billion, lays off an entire team; then invites employees to..
Article Text:
Satya Nadella Steps Back to Focus on AI: Microsoft’s Major Reorganisation Explained

Scale AI Severance and alternative opportunities for laid off employees









Scale AI shut down an entire team of contractors in its Dallas office this week, marking the latest restructuring at the startup since Mark Zuckerberg 's Meta invested $14.3 billion in the company in June. The shuttered team, known internally as the NPO or New Projects Organization, had over a dozen members who focused on generalist tasks such as improving the writing ability of artificial intelligence (AI) chatbots.Scale AI attributed the cuts to an industry shift toward more technical, expert-level training work, according to Business Insider. As AI chatbots improve, they increasingly require input from humans with specialised skills in fields like medicine, robotics, and finance, rather than generalist contractors.“Scale wound down a small experimental onsite program in Dallas staffed by a contract workforce,” Scale AI spokesperson Natalia Montalvo said.“This reflects an industry shift toward higher skill, expert data work. It only affects a small fraction of our overall workforce and has no impact on customer delivery,” Montalvo was quoted as saying.Scale AI offered the laid-off workers four weeks of severance pay and healthcare coverage through October, according to an email from HireArt, a staffing agency used extensively by Scale AI.The recently terminated workers were also invited to join Scale's gig-work platform, Outlier, where thousands of freelancers help train AI models.“As you navigate this transition, we want to ensure you are aware of alternative opportunities,” the email stated.Montalvo added that Scale AI continues to expand expert-level programs and that broader groups of contractors continue to work in Dallas.The Dallas layoffs represent the latest in a series of cuts at Scale AI since the Meta investment. xAI has also made similar moves to focus on specialised AI training, recently downsizing its team of generalist AI tutors in September.
Article Summary: Scale AI shut down an entire team of contractors in its Dallas office this week. Mark Zuckerberg's Meta invested $14.3 billion in the company in June. The shuttered team had over a dozen members who focused on generalist tasks such as improving the writing ability of AI chatbots.

Article Title: Another Apple exec joins Meta's AI team, just weeks after promotion
Article Text:
Meta’s aggressive AI hiring strategy

Siri overhaul faces setback

Apple’s lead AI robotics researcher Zian Jhang quits after 10 years, joins Meta





In a fresh blow to Apple ’s artificial intelligence plans, Ke Yang, a recently promoted executive assigned with leading the company’s AI-driven web search initiate has left the company to join Meta’a AI team. As reported by Bloomberg, Yang has joined Meta after quitting Apple. Yang’s departure from Apple comes just weeks after being appointed as the head of Apple’s Answers, Knowledge and Information (AKI) team, a group central to the upcoming overhaul of the Siri voice assistant.Yang had been with Apple since 2019 and was tapped to spearhead the efforts of the company to make Siri more competitive with generative AI platforms like ChatGPT, features that tap into personal data for more complex user requests. His exit from the company will increase the pressure on Apple in retaining the top AI talent amid growing competition from rivals like OpenAI , Meta and Google Facebook-parent Meta led by CEO Mark Zuckerberg has been aggressively recruiting AI experts to bolster its position in the race towards superintelligence. Yang’s move of joining Meta is followed by a series of high-profile hires by Meta, as the company is ramping up its investment in foundational models and generative AI tools across its platforms.Yang’s departure from Apple could impact the company’s timeline for rolling out its revamped Siri experience which was expected to launch in March next year.The AKI team which takes care of integrating advanced search capabilities and personalized responses into Siri, a key part of Apple’s strategy to catch up with AI-powered assistants from competitors.Last month, Apple’s lead AI researcher for robotics Zian Jhang has left the company to join Meta. According to a Bloomberg report, Jian Zhang has joined the Meta Robotics Studio on September 2. As per the report, three other AI researchers have left Apple’s in-house large language models (LLMs) team. Citing unnamed sources speaking on the condition of anonymity, the report said that these three employees include John Peebles, Nan Du and Zhao Meng. They were all part of an Apple Foundation Models team. While Pebbles and Du are joining OpenAI, Meng is reportedly heading to Anthropic.So far, Apple has lost roughly 10 employees, including chief of the company’s Foundation Models team. The group was central to the creation of the Apple Intelligence platform. According to Bloomberg news, the iPhone maker is now discussing internally whether to rely more on outside technology, rather than just homegrown models.
Article Summary: Ke Yang, a recently promoted executive assigned with leading the company’s AI- driven web search initiate has left the company to join Meta’a AI team. Yang had been with Apple since 2019 and was tapped to spearhead the efforts to make Siri more competitive with generative AI platforms like ChatGPT. His exit from the company will increase the pressure on Apple in retaining the top AI talent.

Article Title: US chipmaker Micron may shut shop in China two years after it settled ban
Article Text:
What Micron has to say on its exit from China data centre business









Micron is reportedly planning to stop supplying server chips to data centers in China after the company failed to recover from a 2023 government ban on its products in critical Chinese infrastructure, a report has said. Micron was the first US chipmaker targeted by Beijing in a move seen as retaliatory for Washington's restrictions aimed at impeding China's semiconductor industry progress.Citing two people briefed on the decision, news agency Reuters reported that Micron will continue to sell to two Chinese customers with data centre operations outside China, including laptop maker Lenovo . The company will also continue supplying chips to auto and mobile phone sector customers in China.Asked about the exit from its China data centre business, Micron said in a statement that the division had been impacted by the ban and that it abides by applicable regulations where it does business.“We have a strong operating and customer presence in China, and China remains an important market for Micron and the semiconductor industry in general,” Micron said in its statement.Micron’s ban from critical infrastructure in China—the world's second-largest market for server memory—has meant the company missed out on the country's data centre expansion boom tied to artificial intelligence (AI) investment.Since Micron's ban, both Nvidia and Intel chips have faced similar accusations from Chinese authorities and an industry group of posing security risks. However, no regulatory action has been taken against those companies.US-China trade tensions and tech rivalry have escalated since 2018, when US President Donald Trump began imposing tariffs on Chinese goods during his first term. That same year, Washington ramped up accusations against Chinese tech giant Huawei, accusing it of representing a national security risk and imposing sanctions a year later.Huawei has denied those charges. Nvidia and Intel have also denied accusations that their products pose risks to Chinese national security. Micron stated in 2023, before the conclusion of China's probe, that it stood by the security of its products.
Article Summary: Micron was the first US chipmaker targeted by Beijing in a move seen as retaliatory for Washington's restrictions aimed at impeding China's semiconductor industry progress. Micron’s ban from critical infrastructure in China has meant the company missed out on the country's data centre expansion boom tied to artificial intelligence.

Article Title: Microsoft sets 'China deadline' for suppliers, instructs: Help us prepare ...
Article Text:
What Microsoft's '2026 China deadline' means





Microsoft is reportedly targeting a major overhaul of its manufacturing operations, with the aim to produce bulk of its upcoming hardware products outside China by as soon as the year 2026. This comes amid escalating US-China trade tensions. According to a report in Nikkei Asia, quoting sources, Microsoft wants to produce the majority of its new products outside of China as early as next year.These initiatives underscore a broader push by American technology companies to disentangle their supply chains from China, driven by geopolitical risks and potential disruptions in bilateral relations. For Microsoft, the effort encompasses preparations for non-China production of its Surface line of laptops and data center servers, spanning everything from core components to final assembly, starting next year, the sources said. Microsoft has asked multiple suppliers to help prepare "out of China" production for its Surface laptop computers and data center servers, including key components and assembly, starting next year, sources briefed on the matter said.One supply chain executive close to the discussions described the initiative to Nikkei as expansive, "The scope is quite wide and covers components, parts and product assembly for new product introductions of both notebook computers and server products."Microsoft is reportedly planning that all of these can be manufactured entirely outside of China starting from 2026 at the earliest. Industry estimates indicate Microsoft distributes around 4 million Surface notebooks and tablets annually, per data from executives and market researcher Omdia. The company has already relocated a substantial share of its server manufacturing away from China since last year, prioritizing these items due to their strategic importance, one source noted. Microsoft is now requiring that no less than 80% of the bill of materials (BOM), which details every part, component, and assembly step—for its servers be sourced internationally. The BOM push is part of a wider strategy, including efforts to ramp up non-China output for Xbox gaming consoles, though full relocation isn't yet mandatory, the source added.A second executive at a Microsoft vendor highlighted the logistical hurdles to Nikkei: "Moving assembly is rather easy, but [shifting production] down to the component level is radical and very challenging, especially with a timeframe like 2026." "We need to see how this ambition will be carried out."The moves align with similar actions by other American tech companies. Amazon's cloud division, AWS, is reportedly scrutinizing reductions in purchases from Chinese printed circuit board maker SYE for its AI servers and evaluating alternatives, while Google is scaling up server assembly in Thailand through expanded partnerships.
Article Summary: Microsoft reportedly targeting major overhaul of its manufacturing operations. Aim is to produce bulk of upcoming hardware products outside China by 2026. This comes amid escalating US-China trade tensions. Microsoft has asked multiple suppliers to help prepare "out of China" production.

Article Title: Teen girl files lawsuit against maker of a 'clothes removal' tool, names Telegram too
Article Text:
AI generated image for representation

What the lawsuit alleges about the AI ‘clothes removal’ tool



“nominal defendant"

“constant fear”





A teenage girl is suing the maker of an AI "clothes removal" tool and Telegram. The lawsuit comes after a classmate used the technology to create at least one non-consensual fake nude image of her when she was 14. The lawsuit, filed by the girl (now 17) from New Jersey, is the latest in a series of legal actions against the companies behind undressing websites and applications. The incident occurred two years ago at Westfield High School, where the girl was one of several students who discovered a classmate had used photos from their social media accounts to generate the fake nude images. According to a Wall Street Journal report, some male classmates also shared the fabricated images in group chats.A Yale Law School professor, a group of his students, and a trial attorney have filed a lawsuit on behalf of the teenager against AI/Robotics Venture Strategy3, the company behind ClothOff. This web tool was allegedly used to generate the images. Telegram is also listed as ain the case, as ClothOff was accessible through bots on the messaging platform. AI/Robotics Venture Strategy3 is registered in the British Virgin Islands and is believed to be run by individuals based in Belarus.It's also important to note that the teenage boy who made the fake images isn’t named in this case but is facing a separate lawsuit. He allegedly used a photo of the girl in a swimsuit to generate the nude picture. The girl says she lives inthat the fake image is circulating online and that photos of her and her classmates are being used to train ClothOff’s AI model.However, the plaintiff argues that creating these images amounts to CSAM, while the developer claims that its tool cannot process photos of minors and that any attempt to do so results in an account ban. The company also says it does not store user data.The plaintiff has asked the court to order AI/Robotics Venture Strategy3 to delete all nude images of adults and children created without consent, stop using them to train AI models, and take down both the website and the ClothOff tool.A Telegram spokesperson said that such tools and non-consensual pornography violate its terms of service and are removed when found. ClothOff has since been taken down from Telegram, the report adds.Last year, The Guardian investigated ClothOff, which had over 4 million monthly visitors. The report found that the app had been used to make fake nude images of children globally.The issue of AI-generated nudes without consent existed even before generative AI became popular. In 2020, a Telegram deepfake bot was found to have created over 100,000 fake nude images of women using social media photos.In 2024, the San Francisco Attorney’s office filed lawsuits against 16 undressing websites, and in June this year, Meta sued the developer of the Crush AI nudify app after 8,000 related ads appeared on its platforms within two weeks.
Article Summary: Teenager is suing the maker of an AI "clothes removal" tool and Telegram. The lawsuit comes after a classmate used the technology to create at least one non- consensual fake nude image of her when she was 14. A Yale Law School professor, a group of his students, and a trial attorney have filed a lawsuit on behalf of the teenager.

Article Title: Infosys headcount grows by 14,000-plus in Q2: Company sends 'mass emails' to senior employees on hiring; says, 'Visit campus and ...'
Article Text:
Infosys

Infosys sends employees to campus for hiring drive



Infosys second quarter profit jumps 13%







India’s second-largest IT services company, Infosys , added 8,203 employees during the second quarter of the fiscal year 2025-26. This is the fifth consecutive quarter of headcount addition for the company. Infosys' employee count has jumped by 14,203 from a year ago. The Bengaluru-headquartered company reported these numbers while announcing its second quarter financial numbers. In comparison, in the previous quarter ending June, Infosys had added only 210 employees. At the end of the September quarter, it had 3,31,991 employees, higher than the June quarter’s 3,23,788.During the quarter, Infosys reportedly invited its senior employees to be on panels to visit colleges and interview students for jobs at the software giant, signalling a revival of campus hiring after two years. Their remit would be to visit colleges across the country and recruit digital specialist engineers (DSE).According to a report in Economic Times, this is the first time that Infosys sent a mass email to senior employees at the job levels of manager and above. As per the email seen by ET, Infosys executives are asked to assess the potential candidates on programming fundamentals and problem-solving skills required for entry-level DSE roles.The email said that senior employees at job-level five (JL5) and above with at least one year of service at the company and with a performance rating of ‘met expectations’ or above can offer themselves to be on the panels. It said that they will visit campuses and conduct in-person interviews for roles at its development centres pan-India.On October 16, Infosys posted a 13.2 per cent increase in consolidated net profit at Rs 7,364 crore for the second quarter ended September 30, 2025. The company had logged a net profit of Rs 6,506 crore in the same period a year ago.Revenue from operations grew 8.6 per cent to Rs 44,490 crore during the quarter from Rs 40,986 crore a year ago. The company increased the lower base of the growth outlook for FY26 to 2-3 per cent in constant currency terms from 1-3 per cent it had projected in the June 2025 quarter."We had a strong performance in Q2. Our operating margin was 21 per cent. Deals were at USD 3.1 billion out of which 67 per cent were net new work. In addition, we announced a mega deal worth USD 1.6 billion after the close of the quarter. We have added 8,000 employees during the quarter," Infosys MD and CEO Salil Parikh said.Infosys announced an interim dividend of Rs 23 per share, an increase of 9.5 per cent over the last fiscal.
Article Summary: Infosys' employee count has jumped by 14,203 from a year ago. In comparison, in the previous quarter ending June, Infosys had added only 210 employees. At the end of the September quarter, it had 3,31,991 employees.

Article Title: Apple founder Steve Jobs to feature on US $1 commemorative coin in 2026
Article Text:
'Make Something Wonderful' inscription honours Jobs' legacy

Collectible coins available for purchase in 2026







The United States Mint has announced that Apple co-founder Steve Jobs will be honoured on a commemorative $1 coin as part of the 2026 American Innovation Program, celebrating his transformative impact on personal computing and technology.The coin depicts a young Jobs sitting cross-legged against Northern California's oak-covered rolling hills, wearing his signature turtleneck. The design was created by Elana Hagler and sculpted by Phebe Hemphill, capturing Jobs in a moment of reflection that symbolises how California's landscape inspired his vision to make technology intuitive and accessible.The coin features the inscription "Make Something Wonderful," taken from a popular Jobs quote and the title of a posthumous book of his writings released in 2023. Jobs founded Apple with Steve Wozniak in 1976, releasing the Apple I that year and the influential Apple II in 1977. During his second tenure at Apple beginning in 1997, he oversaw the release of revolutionary products including the iPhone, MacBook Air, and iMac.California Governor Gavin Newsom recommended Jobs for the honour earlier this year, stating that Jobs "encapsulates the unique brand of innovation that California runs on". Jobs himself once reflected on California's influence, noting the state's sense of experimentation and openness to new possibilities.The coins will be available for purchase at $13.25 each from the U.S. Mint website, with sets of four coins costing approximately $27.50 to $30. The 2026 collection also honours Iowa's Dr. Norman Borlaug, Wisconsin's Cray-1 supercomputer, and Minnesota's mobile refrigeration innovation.The American Innovation coin series began in 2018 and will continue until 2032, featuring significant innovations from all 50 states, the District of Columbia, and five US territories. Jobs died in 2011 from cancer complications and received the Presidential Medal of Freedom posthumously in 2022.
Article Summary: Apple co-founder honoured on a commemorative $1 coin as part of the 2026 American Innovation Program. The coin features the inscription "Make Something Wonderful," taken from a popular Jobs quote and the title of a posthumous book of his writings. The American Innovation coin series began in 2018 and will continue until 2032.

Article Title: LinkedIn’s Reid Hoffman on why he tells founders of companies he invests in to ask: How do I think I am different than Elon Musk as partner
Article Text:
A different kind of partner



Beyond resumes: The power of referrals







LinkedIn co-founder Reid Hoffman recently appeared on an episode of ‘Possible’ podcast where he revealed a unique approach to startup due diligence: he urge the founders to investigate his background including speaking to people who had negative experiences working with him before accepted his investment. “You’re allowed to talk to anyone,” Hoffman said. “I will identify people to you who I think are my negative references.”As reported by Business Insider, Hoffman also emphasised that trust and transparency are foundational to any investor-founder relationship. Hoffman also added that he gave OpenAI president Greg Brockman a list of references before investing in the AI startup, shortly after Elon Musk exited the company in 2018.As per the report by Business Insider, Hoffman has also encouraged the founders to ask questions they might otherwise avoid, “One of the natural questions you guys should ask… is how do I think that I’m different than Elon as a partner,” Hoffman told Brockman and OpenAI CEO Sam Altman.The comments made by Hoffman reflects on his belief that founders should evaluate not just the capital, but character and compatibility at the time of selecting investors.Hoffman was served on OpenAI’s board from 2019 to 2023 and has invested in many companies such as Airbnb , Aurora, and Joby Aviation, is a strong advocate for reference-based hiring and investing.In a July LinkedIn post, he wrote: “Give more weight to references than to interviews or résumés… What they often miss is how someone behaves under pressure, in uncertainty, with a team.”
Article Summary: LinkedIn co-founder Reid Hoffman recently appeared on an episode of ‘Possible’ podcast where he revealed a unique approach to startup due diligence. Hoffman also added that he gave OpenAI president Greg Brockman a list of references before investing in the AI startup, shortly after Elon Musk exited the company.

Article Title: Salesforce faces lawsuit from authors over AI training practices
Article Text:
Authors demand accountability



Salesforce responds







A group of known authors has flied a lawsuit against tech giant Salesforce. The group alleges that the company’s artificial intelligence software was trained on their copyrighted works without their permission. According to Reuters, the lawsuit filed in the federal court accuses Salesforce of infringing with the intellectual property rights via its partnership with Cohere, a Canadian AI firm whose language models are integrated into Salesforce’s enterprise tools.The plaintiffs include bestselling writers like Jonathan Franzen, Jodi Picoult, and George Saunders, who claim their books were used to train Cohere’s AI models, which power features in Salesforce’s Einstein Copilot and other generative tools. The lawsuit mirrors similar legal actions taken against OpenAI and Meta, as authors push back against what they describe as unauthorized use of their creative output.As reported by Reuters, the complaint filed argues that Salesfoce and Cohere violated copyright law by using literary works without consent or compensation. The lawsuit seeks damages and an injection to prevent further use of the authors’ content in AI training.“This is about protecting the value of human creativity,” said a spokesperson for the plaintiffs. “Tech companies must be held accountable when they exploit copyrighted material to build commercial products. ”As per the Reuters report, Salesforce has not yet commented on the lawsuits but it is expected to defend its practices by pointing to its licensing agreements and data sourcing protocols. Cohere, which provides foundational models for Salesforce’s AI features, has also been named in the suit.
Article Summary: A group of known authors has flied a lawsuit against tech giant Salesforce. The group alleges that the company’s artificial intelligence software was trained on their copyrighted works without their permission. The lawsuit seeks damages and an injection to prevent further use of the authors’ content in AI training.

Article Title: Hacked: Public announcement systems at three airports in Canada to broadcast pro-Hamas and anti-Donald Trump messages
Article Text:
Cybercriminals hacked third-party software



‘F**k Trump & Netanyahu’: Pro-Hamas Messages Blasted At North American, Canadian Airports | Watch





Hackers compromised the public address (PA) systems at four airports – three in Canada and one in the US – to broadcast messages praising Hamas and criticising President Donald Trump, according to officials and reports. The affected Canadian airports—all smaller, regional facilities—included Kelowna International Airport and Victoria International Airport, both in British Columbia, and Windsor International Airport in Ontario. The single US target was Harrisburg International Airport in Pennsylvania.According to a report by news agency Reuters, in Kelowna, an "advertisement streaming service" was "briefly compromised and unauthorised content was shared." The Royal Canadian Mounted Police (RCMP) is investigating the hack.At Victoria International Airport, hackers broadcast messages in a foreign language and played music over the PA system, according to an airport spokesperson. The hackers gained access by breaching third-party software, forcing the airport to switch to an internal system to regain control. The Canadian Centre for Cyber Security is assisting with that investigation.The PA system and flight information display screens were also breached at Windsor International Airport in Ontario, displaying “unauthorized images and announcements.” Airport officials confirmed the breach occurred via a “cloud-based software provider” and stated that “our systems returned to normal shortly thereafter.”Meanwhile, US Transportation Secretary Sean Duffy confirmed the breach at Harrisburg International Airport in Pennsylvania in a social media post. The US Federal Aviation Administration (FAA) and airport officials are investigating the incident, though the FAA did not immediately respond to a request for comment.The four locations targeted are all smaller, regional airports. The busiest among them, Kelowna, served just over 2 million passengers in 2024, significantly fewer than the more than 25 million travelers who used British Columbia's largest airport, Vancouver International Airport.
Article Summary: Hackers compromised the public address (PA) systems at four airports – three in Canada and one in the US – to broadcast messages praising Hamas and criticising President Donald Trump. The affected Canadian airports—all smaller, regional facilities—included Kelowna International Airport and Victoria International Airport. The single US target was Harrisburg International Airport in Pennsylvania.

Article Title: Deloitte's Global AI Leader Nitin Mittal warns job loss to AI is ‘inevitable’, but engineers should…..
Article Text:
Workers must adapt to survive in the AI era: Nitin Mittal







Deloitte's Global AI Leader Nitin Mittal has said that engineers should not fear artificial intelligence (AI) itself, but rather their colleagues who are learning to use it faster. At the NDTV World Summit 2025, Mittal was asked the much-debated question — whether AI will take away jobs — Mittal said yes, some roles will be affected.“It is inevitable that certain jobs will be impacted, like software engineering, customer support, call centres and coding,” he said. “But I have not come across a single job that has been lost to AI. Almost all jobs are impacted by another person who has figured out how to work with AI.”Mittal, co-author of the Wall Street Journal bestseller All-in on AI, said that people who fail to adapt or reskill are more likely to be left behind. “Those who don’t show curiosity to learn and instead spend their time doomscrolling will likely get displaced,” he remarked.He said instead of fearing job losses, people should focus on the rise of a new AI-driven economy that will also create fresh opportunities. “The new AI economy could create jobs that no one imagined, but it will require reskilling,” he said.During the interaction, Nitin Mittal also pointed out that building AI data centres will generate new construction and manufacturing jobs, supporting local industries. He also called for developing sovereign AI models in India to preserve the country’s culture and languages.“India must leverage its strengths — the scale of its talent, entrepreneurship, and innovation — to build and apply AI effectively,” he said.When asked about self-driving Waymo cabs and whether such technology could work on Indian roads, Mittal said the focus should shift from importing solutions to building them locally. “The conversation should be about what we can make, design, build, test, and deploy in India,” he said.
Article Summary: Deloitte's Global AI Leader Nitin Mittal has said that engineers should not fear artificial intelligence (AI) itself, but rather their colleagues who are learning to use it faster. Mittal said instead of fearing job losses, people should focus on the rise of a new AI-driven economy that will also create fresh opportunities.

Article Title: Silicon Valley's prominent venture capitalist Ron Conway quits Salesforce Foundation; sends 'angry' email to CEO Marc Benioff
Article Text:
Marc Benioff’s remarks draw outrage





Salesforce CEO Marc Benioff recently said that he supports President Donald Trump's deployment of the National Guard in San Francisco. The remarks have prompted the resignation of Ron Conway, a prominent Silicon Valley venture capitalist and longtime friend of Benioff. In an email to Benioff, Conway said their values were no longer aligned.“It saddens me immensely to say that with your recent comments, and failure to understand their impact, I now barely recognize the person I have so long admired,” Conway wrote in the email, obtained by The New York Times.“I have expressed candidly to you, repeatedly, in recent days, that I am shocked and disappointed by your comments calling for an unwanted invasion of San Francisco by federal troops,” Conway wrote, “and by your willful ignorance and detachment from the impacts of the ICE immigration raids of families with NO criminal record.”Conway, an early investor in Google and Facebook , stepped down Thursday, October 16 from the board of the Salesforce Foundation, which had about $400 million in assets at the end of 2023. Ron Conway and Marc Benioff, close friends for more than 25 years, had discussed Benioff’s remarks in recent days, but Conway said he remained unconvinced that Benioff understood “the dangers posed by the Trump administration” or “the impact of his remarks.”The controversy began after Salesforce CEO Marc Benioff told The New York Times last week that he fully supports Trump and wanted National Guard troops sent to San Francisco, where Salesforce is headquartered, to curb crime. The billionaire executive, once known for his progressive stance, angered city leaders with his comments.Conway criticized Benioff for weighing in on San Francisco’s issues “where you don’t even live or vote.” Benioff currently resides on the Big Island of Hawaii, where he owns several properties and is registered to vote.President Trump said Wednesday that San Francisco could be the next city to receive federal troops, praising “great support” for the idea — a possible reference to Benioff and Elon Musk, who also backed the move.Conway also took aim at Benioff’s repeated threats to move Salesforce’s annual Dreamforce conference to Las Vegas over safety concerns. “Your obsession with and constant annual threats to move Dreamforce to Las Vegas is ironic, since it is a fact that Las Vegas has a higher rate of violent crime than San Francisco,” Conway wrote. “San Francisco does not need a federal invasion because you don’t like paying for extra security for Dreamforce. ”
Article Summary: Salesforce CEO Marc Benioff recently said that he supports President Donald Trump's deployment of the National Guard in San Francisco. The remarks have prompted the resignation of Ron Conway, a prominent Silicon Valley venture capitalist. Conway said their values were no longer aligned.

Article Title: Google CEO Sundar Pichai on the launch that made the company issue Code Red to all its employees
Article Text:
Google To Invest $15 Billion On AI Hub In Visakhapatnam, CEO Sundar Pichai Speaks To PM Modi

Founders pulled from retirement to fight AI battle

From panic to opportunity in silicon valley's AI arms race





Google CEO Sundar Pichai has opened up about the company's internal panic when OpenAI launched ChatGPT in late 2022, describing how the seemingly small startup's breakthrough forced the company to declare a "code red" and dramatically reshape its AI strategy.Speaking at Salesforce's Dreamforce conference, Pichai acknowledged that OpenAI deserved credit for releasing their chatbot first, even though Google had been developing similar technology internally. "But you're right, credit to OpenAI, they put it out first," he said. "We knew in a different world, we would've probably launched our chatbot maybe a few months down the line," he added, noting the product hadn't reached Google's quality standards at the time.The admission highlighted a familiar Silicon Valley dilemma: the tension between moving fast and maintaining brand reputation. For Google, the calculus was different than for a relatively unknown startup willing to take risks.The ChatGPT phenomenon prompted drastic measures at Google headquarters. Larry Page and Sergey Brin—the company's founders who had stepped away from daily operations in 2019—were summoned back to confront what insiders recognised as an existential crisis.Their return signalled the gravity of the situation: a nimble startup had potentially found a way to disrupt Google's $149 billion search empire.The company swiftly mobilised, reassigning teams across departments and green lighting more than 20 AI initiatives. Executives understood the danger clearly—ChatGPT's conversational interface offered a fundamentally different way to access information online, one that could render traditional search obsolete. With digital advertising generating over 80 percent of Google's revenue, the threat cut straight to the company's financial lifeline.Contrary to external perceptions of crisis, Pichai characterised his reaction as optimistic. "I was excited because I knew the window had shifted," he revealed, suggesting ChatGPT's launch validated the AI investments Google had been making behind closed doors.The company's response included launching Bard—later rebranded as Gemini—in March 2023. Yet Google's measured approach reflected its unique position: unlike a relatively unknown startup, the company couldn't afford missteps with experimental technology that might produce biased, toxic, or inaccurate responses.Pichai drew parallels to previous technological disruptions, including YouTube's surprise emergence while Google developed video search, and Instagram's sudden popularity as Facebook dominated photo-sharing—both eventual acquisitions that turned competitive threats into strategic victories.
Article Summary: Google CEO Sundar Pichai opened up about the company's internal panic when OpenAI launched ChatGPT in late 2022. The company swiftly mobilised, reassigning teams across departments and green lighting more than 20 AI initiatives. Larry Page and Sergey Brin were summoned back to confront what insiders recognised as an existential crisis.

Article Title: AI investment boom reaches Europe's currency market, and the two biggest winners are ...
Article Text:
UK and Sweden lead AI investment destinations in Europe





The surge in artificial intelligence (AI) investment is beginning to influence currency markets in Europe. According to an analysis by news agency Reuters, investment boom in artificial intelligence is starting to be felt for the first time in currency markets across Europe, and analysts reckon Swedish crown and sterling stand to benefit the most. The $10 trillion-a-day foreign exchange (FX) market has been shaped by a weakening U.S. dollar this year, driven by tariff concerns and expectations of U.S. interest rate cuts. However, the ripple effects of AI, which has propelled stock markets to record highs, are now impacting currencies.JPMorgan analysts note that the Swedish crown (Krona) and sterling have shown resilience in recent months, partly due to significant AI investments in Sweden and Britain. "Sweden and the UK stand out in terms of AI investment, providing a tailwind to their currencies, even if modest," a JPMorgan spokesperson told Reuters.According to Stanford University’s AI index, the UK and Sweden each attracted over $4 billion in private AI investments last year, ranking third and fourth globally behind the U.S. and China. The Swedish krona has been the top-performing major European currency against the dollar in 2025, rising nearly 15%, while sterling has gained 7%.Analysts caution that isolating AI’s precise impact on currency movements is challenging due to factors like interest rate expectations and fiscal concerns, particularly for sterling."Large AI investments announced in both countries could certainly have created some demand for sterling and the Swedish crown, contributing to their resilience," Jane Foley, Rabobank’s head of FX strategy, told the news agency. The Krona has also strengthened against the euro and other Scandinavian currencies, while sterling has weakened against the euro and Swiss franc due to fiscal uncertainties. Foley explained that AI investments in Swedish companies, which increase demand for the krona, can cause noticeable currency spikes. However, sterling’s response is less pronounced because it is the world’s fourth most-traded currency, accounting for over 10% of global FX trades, compared to the krona’s less than 2%, per the Bank for International Settlements.In September 2025, Britain and the U.S. reportedly signed a technology pact, with U.S. firms, led by Microsoft, pledging £31 billion ($42 billion) in UK investments. In Sweden, AI giant Nvidia plans to supply its data center platform to companies like Ericsson and AstraZeneca, while Microsoft, Meta, Alphabet, and Brookfield Asset Management are planning data centers, leveraging Sweden’s reliable electricity and infrastructure. These developments create a favorable environment for both currencies, analysts say.A report by SEB earlier this year showed Swedish FX market participants holding near-record overweight positions in the krona. Kenneth Broux, Societe Generale’s head of corporate research for FX and rates, said that U.S. tech investment pledges could reduce pessimism ahead of Britain’s November 2025 budget, where tax hikes are expected, boosting sterling’s appeal. He added that AI-driven “reskilling and upskilling” could mitigate pressures on welfare and unemployment benefits in aging Western economies.
Article Summary: Sweden and the UK each attracted over $4 billion in private AI investments last year. The Swedish krona has been the top-performing major European currency against the dollar in 2025. sterling has weakened against the euro and Swiss franc due to fiscal uncertainties.
